eu.fbk.knowledgestore.data

Class Stream<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.fbk.knowledgestore.data.Stream<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of element returned by the Stream
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable, Iterable<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SearchResponseStream

    public abstract class Stream<T>
extends Object
implements Iterable<T>, Closeable
    A stream of typed elements that can be consumed at most once.

    A Stream returns a sequence of elements (e.g., the results of a retrieval API operation) one at a time, after which it is no more usable, allowing manipulation and consumption of elements it in a number of way.

    A Stream can be created:

    • using one of the static create() factory methods starting from an array, an Iterable, an Iterator, a Sesame Iteration or an Enumeration of elements;
    • concatenating zero or more Streams or Iterables, via concat(Iterable) or concat(Iterable...);
    • subclassing the Stream class and overriding at least one of protected methods doIterator() and doToHandler(Handler) (the default implementation of each of them is based on the implementation of the other one).

    While the first method supports the usual external iteration / pull-like pattern based on Iterators, the second supports an internal iteration / push-like pattern where iterated elements are forwarded to an Handler and control of the iteration is maintained by the Stream. Although implementing external iteration should be preferred (as more flexible and immediately convertible to internal iteration), there are cases where only internal iteration is feasible (e.g., because more simple to implement, or because the ultimate source of the iterated elements is a third party library that supports only an internal iteration / push like approach, such as Sesame parsers). In these cases, conversion from internal iteration to external iteration is automatically performed by the Stream using a background thread and an element queue.

    Two main families of operations are offered: intermediate operations and terminal operations (as in JDK 8 streams).

    Intermediate operations return new Stream wrappers that lazily manipulate elements of a source Stream while they are traversed, or otherwise enrich the source Stream, and can be chained in a fluent style. These operations are:

    • element filtering, via sequential or parallel filter() methods;
    • element transformation, via sequential or parallel transform() methods;
    • duplicate removal, via distinct();
    • element slicing, via slice(long, long);
    • element chunking, via chunk(int);
    • iteration timeout, via #timeout(long).

    Terminal operations consume the elements of the stream. At most a terminal operation can be invoked on a Stream, reflecting the fact that elements can be accessed only once. Before invoking it, the Stream is available; after invoking it, the Stream is consumed and no other intermediate or terminal operation can be called on it. Terminal operations are:

    • element counting, via count();
    • external, pull-style iteration, via iterator();
    • internal, push-style iteration, via toHandler(Handler);
    • array construction, via toArray(Class);
    • immutable List construction, via toList();
    • immutable Set construction, via toSet();
    • immutable sorted List construction, via toSortedList(Comparator);
    • immutable SortedSet construction, via toSortedSet(Comparator);
    • Map population or immutable Map construction, via toMap() methods;
    • Multimap population or immutable Multimap construction, via toMultimap() methods;
    • unique element extraction, via getUnique() and getUnique(Object);

    Streams are thread safe. They implement the Iterable interface, hence can be used in enhanced for loops, and the Closeable interface, as they may wrap underlying resources (e.g., network connections) that need to be closed. Closing a Stream causes the call of method doClose(), which can be overridden by subclasses to perform additional cleanup. Note that closing a Stream will cause any pending terminal operation to be interrupted (on a best effort basis), resulting in an exception being thrown by that operation. Also, completion of a terminal operation automatically causes the Stream to be closed (as it cannot be used in any other way).

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a Stream over the supplied elements

        Parameters:
        iterable - an Iterable of non-null elements, possibly empty but not null

      • filter

        public final Stream<T> filter(Predicate<? super T> predicate,
                              int parallelism)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with only the elements of this Stream that satisfy the specified predicate. If parallelism > 1, up to parallelism evaluations of the predicate are simultaneously performed in background threads for greater throughput.
        Parameters:
        predicate - the predicate, never called with a null input
        parallelism - the parallelism degree, i.e., the maximum number of predicate evaluations that can be performed in parallel (if <= 1 no parallel evaluation will be performed)
        Returns:
        a Stream over the elements satisfying the predicate

      • transform

        public final <R> Stream<R> transform(Function<? super T,? extends R> function,
                                     int parallelism)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with the elements obtained from the ones of this Stream by applying the specified transformation function. Method Function.apply(Object) is called to transform each input element into an output element. If parallelism > 1, up to parallelism evaluations of the function are simultaneously performed in background threads for greater throughput. Note that the function is never called with a null input; in case it returns a null output, it is ignored and iteration moves to the next element (this feature can be used to combine filtering with transformation).
        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of transformed elements
        Parameters:
        function - the function, not null
        parallelism - the parallelism degree, i.e., the maximum number of function evaluations that can be performed in parallel (if <= 1 no parallel evaluation will be performed)
        Returns:
        a Stream over the transformed elements

      • transform

        public final <R> Stream<R> transform(@Nullable
                                     Function<Iterator<T>,Iterator<R>> iteratorFunction,
                                     @Nullable
                                     Function<Handler<R>,Handler<T>> handlerFunction)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with the elements obtained by applying the supplied transformation functions to the Iterator and Handler returned / accepted by this Stream. At least a function must be supplied. If both of them are supplied, make sure that they perform the same transformation.
        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of transformed elements
        Parameters:
        iteratorFunction - the transformation function responsible to adapt the Iterator returned by this Stream
        handlerFunction - the transformation function responsible to adapt the Handler accepted by this Stream
        Returns:
        a Stream over the transformed sequence of elements

      • transform

        public final <R> Stream<R> transform(Class<R> type,
                                     boolean lenient,
                                     Object... path)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with the elements obtained by applying an optional navigation path and conversion to a certain type to the elements of this Stream. The path is a sequence of keys (Strings, URIs, generic objects) that are applied to Record, BindingSet, Map and Multimap elements to extract child elements in a recursive fashion. Starting from an element returned by this stream, the result of this navigation process is a list of (sub-)child elements that are converted to the requested type (via Data.convert(Object, Class)) and concatenated in the resulting stream; Iterables, Iterators and arrays found during the navigation are exploded and their elements individually considered. The lenient parameters controls whether conversion errors should be ignored or result in an exception being thrown by the returned Stream.
        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of resulting elements
        Parameters:
        type - the class resulting elements should be converted to
        lenient - true if conversion errors should be ignored
        path - a vararg array of zero or more keys that recursively select the elements to return
        Returns:
        a Stream over the elements obtained applying the navigation path and the conversion specified

      • distinct

        public final Stream<T> distinct()
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with only the distinct elements of this Stream. Duplicates are removed lazily during the iteration. Note that duplicate removal requires to keep track of the elements seen, so an amount of memory proportional to the number of elements in the Stream is required.
        Returns:
        a Stream over de-duplicated elements

      • slice

        public final Stream<T> slice(long offset,
                             long limit)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream with max limit elements with index starting at offset taken from this Stream. After those elements are returned, the wrapped Stream is automatically closed.
        Parameters:
        offset - the offset where to start returning elements from, not negative
        limit - the maximum number of elements to return (starting from offset), not negative
        Returns:
        a Stream wrapping this Stream and limiting the number of returned elements

        Parameters:
        chunkSize - the chunk size, positive
        Returns:
        a Stream wrapping this Stream and returning chunks of elements

      • track

        public final Stream<T> track(@Nullable
                             AtomicLong counter,
                             @Nullable
                             AtomicBoolean eof)
        Intermediate operation returning a Stream that returns the elements of this Stream and tracks the number of elements returned so far. As tracking the number elements has a small cost (due to Iterator and Handler wrapping, this feature must be explicitly requested and is not offered as part of the default feature set of Stream.
        Parameters:
        counter - the variable where to hold the number of returned elements, possibly null
        eof - the variable where to store whether end of sequence has been reached, possibly null
        Returns:
        a Stream tracking the number of returned elements

      • count

        public final long count()
        Terminal operation returning the number of elements in this Stream. Note that only few elements are materialized at any time, so it is safe to use this method with arbitrarily large Streams.
        Returns:
        the number of elements in this Stream

      • toHandler

        public final void toHandler(Handler<? super T> handler)
        Terminal operations that forwards all the elements of this Stream to the Handler specified. No explicit mechanism is provided for interrupting the Iteration, although many Streams may react to the standard Thread.interrupt() signal to stop iteration.
        Parameters:
        handler - the Handler where to forward elements

        public final Set<T> toSet()

      • toSortedList

        public final List<T> toSortedList(Comparator<? super T> comparator)
        Terminal operation returning an immutable List with all the elements of this Stream, sorted using the supplied Comparator. Use Ordering.natural() to sort Comparable elements based on Comparable.compareTo(Object) order. Call this method only if there is enough memory to hold the resulting List.
        Parameters:
        comparator - the Comparator to sort elements, not null
        Returns:
        the resulting immutable sorted list

      • toSortedList

        public final List<T> toSortedList(Class<? extends Comparable<?>> type,
                                  boolean lenient,
                                  Object... path)
        Terminal operation returning an immutable List with all the elements of this Stream, sorted based on a sort key obtained by applying an optional navigation path and conversion to a specified type. The path is a sequence of keys (Strings, URIs, generic objects) that are applied to Record, BindingSet, Map and Multimap elements to extract child elements in a recursive fashion. Starting from an element returned by this stream, the result of this navigation process is either null or a Comparable key object that is converted to the requested type (via Data.convert(Object, Class)) and used for comparing the element with other element. The lenient parameters controls whether conversion errors should be ignored or result in an exception being thrown.
        Parameters:
        type - the class of the sort key
        lenient - true if conversion errors should be ignored
        path - a vararg array of zero or more keys that recursively select the sort key
        Returns:
        the resulting immutable sorted list

      • toSortedSet

        public final SortedSet<T> toSortedSet(Comparator<? super T> comparator)
        Terminal operation returning an immutable SortedSet with all the elements of this Stream, sorted using the supplied Comparator. Use Ordering.natural() to sort Comparable elements based on Comparable.compareTo(Object) order. Call this method only if there is enough memory to hold the resulting SortedSet.
        Parameters:
        comparator - the Comparator to sort elements, not null
        Returns:
        the resulting immutable SortedSet

      • toCollection

        public final <C extends Collection<? super T>> C toCollection(C collection)

      • toMap

        public final <K,V> Map<K,V> toMap(Function<? super T,? extends K> keyFunction,
                                  Function<? super T,? extends V> valueFunction)
        Terminal operation returning an immutable Map indexing the elements of this Stream as <key, value> pairs computed using the supplied Functions. The supplied key and value Functions are called for each element, producing the keys and values to store in the Map. If a null key or value are produced, the element is discarded. If multiple values are mapped to the same key, only the most recently computed one will be stored. Use Functions.identity() in case no transformation is required to extract the key and/or the value.
        Type Parameters:
        K - the type of key
        V - the type of value
        Parameters:
        keyFunction - the key function
        valueFunction - the value function
        Returns:
        an immutable Map with the computed <key, value> pairs

      • toMap

        public final <K,V,M extends Map<K,V>> M toMap(Function<? super T,? extends K> keyFunction,
                                              Function<? super T,? extends V> valueFunction,
                                              M map)
        Terminal operation storing the elements of this Stream in the supplied map as <key, value> pairs computed using the supplied Functions. The supplied key and value Functions are called for each element, producing the keys and values to store in the Map. If a null key or value are produced, the element is discarded. If multiple values are mapped to the same key, only the most recently computed one will be stored. Use Functions.identity() in case no transformation is required to extract the key and/or the value.
        Type Parameters:
        K - the type of key
        V - the type of value
        M - the type of Map
        Parameters:
        keyFunction - the key function
        valueFunction - the value function
        map - the Map where to store the extracted <key, value> pairs
        Returns:
        the supplied Map

      • getUnique

        public final T getUnique(T defaultValue)
        Terminal operation returning the only element in this Stream, or the default value specified if there are no elements, multiple elements or an Exception occurs.
        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the default value to return if a unique value cannot be extracted
        Returns:
        the only element in this Stream, or the default value in case that element does not exist, there are multiple elements or an Exception occurs

      • getUnique

        @Nullable
public final T getUnique()
                            throws IllegalStateException
        Terminal operation returning the only element in this Stream, or null if there are no elements. An exception is thrown in case there is more than one element in the Stream. This method is designed for being used with Streams that are expected to return exactly one element, for which it embeds the check on the number of elements.
        Returns:
        the only element in the Stream
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - in case there are multiple elements in the Stream

      • getProperty

        public final <V> V getProperty(String name,
                               Class<V> type)
        Returns a metadata property about the stream. Note that Stream wrappers obtained through intermediate operations don't have their own properties, but instead access the metadata properties of the source Stream.
        Type Parameters:
        V - the type of value
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the property
        type - the type of the property value (conversion will be attempted if available value has a different type)
        Returns:
        the value of the property, or null if the property is undefined

      • setProperty

        public final Stream<T> setProperty(String name,
                                   @Nullable
                                   Object value)
        Sets a metadata property about the stream. Note that Stream wrappers obtained through intermediate operations don't have their own properties, but instead access the metadata properties of the source Stream.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the property
        value - the value of the property, null to clear it
        Returns:
        this Stream, for call chaining

        Returns:

      • setTimeout

        public final Stream<T> setTimeout(@Nullable
                                  Long timestamp)
        Sets a timeout by supplying the absolute milliseconds timestamp when the Stream will be forcedly closed. If the supplied value is null, any previously set timeout is removed. In case the Stream has already been closed, or has just timed out due to a previously set timeout, calling this method has no effect.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - the milliseconds timestamp when the Stream will be closed
        Returns:
        this Stream, for call chaining

      • isAvailable

        public final boolean isAvailable()
        Checks whether this Stream is available, i.e., intermediate and terminal operations can be called. Invoking a terminal operation or closing the Stream will make it non-available.
        Returns:
        true, if the Stream is available

      • isClosed

        public final boolean isClosed()
        Checks whether this Stream has been closed. Note that a Stream is automatically closed when consumption of its elements by a terminal operation completes.
        Returns:
        true, if the Stream has been closed

      • onClose

        public final Stream<T> onClose(Object... objects)
        Register zero or more objects for activation when this Stream will be closed. Each supplied object can be a Closeable, in which case method Closeable.close() will be called, a Runnable, in which case method Runnable.run() will be called, or a Callable, in which casle method Callable.call() will be called; any other type of object will be rejected resulting in an exception. In case the Stream has already been closed, activation of supplied objects will be done immediately.
        Parameters:
        objects - the objects to activate when the Stream will be closed
        Returns:
        this Stream, for call chaining.

      • close

        public final void close()
        Closes this Stream and releases any resource associated to it. The operation causes any Stream wrapping or wrapped by this Stream to be closed. If element iteration through a terminal operation is in progress, it is interrupted resulting in an exception being thrown. If this Stream has already been closed, then calling this method has no effect.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Closeable
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable

      • toString

        public final String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this Stream. The resulting string depends on the actual Stream class. For wrapper Streams, it shows the wrapper parameters and the wrapping hierarchy.
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of this Stream

      • doIterator

        protected Iterator<T> doIterator()
                          throws Throwable
        Implementation method responsible of producing an Iterator over the elements of the Stream. This method is called by iterator() with the guarantee that it is called at most once and with the Stream in the available state. If the returned Iterator implements the Closeable interface, it will be automatically closed when the Stream is closed.
        Returns:
        an Iterator over the elements of the Stream
        Throws:
        Throwable - in case of failure

      • doToHandler

        protected void doToHandler(Handler<? super T> handler)
                    throws Throwable
        Implementation methods responsible of forwarding all the elements of the Stream to the Handler specified. This method is called by toHandler(Handler) to perform internal iteration, with the guarantee that it is called at most once and with the Stream in the available state. As a best practice, the method should intercept Thread.interrupt() requests and stop iteration, if possible; also remember to call Handler.handle(Object) with a null argument after the last element is reached, in order to signal the end of the sequence.
        Parameters:
        handler - the Handler where to forward elements
        Throws:
        Throwable - in case of failure

      • doToString

        @Nullable
protected String doToString()
        Implementation method supporting the generation of a string representation of this Stream. The method should return any parameter / state characterizing this Stream, which is then included within angular brackets in the String denoting the Stream structure.
        Returns:
        an optional string with the arguments / state characterizing this Stream, possibly null

      • doClose

        protected void doClose()
                throws Throwable
        Implementation method responsible of closing optional resources associated to this Stream. The default implementation does nothing.
        Throws:
        Throwable - in case of failure

      • finalize

        protected void finalize()
                 throws Throwable
        Overrides:
        finalize in class Object
        Throws:
        Throwable
